segments.text: So now, in definition then of what you consider perhaps the three major areas in which oceanography is going, if you were going to tell a young oceanographer what he should stress in his scientific backgrounds, what would you choose?
Well, I emphasize that I think oceanography is going to go several major different ways in different sciences.
So I think I'd say the same thing that I was told 20 years ago, that you want to get a good strong background in one of the basic sciences before getting into oceanography.
And that
your value in oceanography will depend to a large extent on how well you bring those basic principles into the field of oceanography.
Because oceanography, as you've alluded to a couple of times, is a very broad subject.
It involves all the sciences.
But to get into oceanography from a generalist point of view means you don't bring any expertise yourself into the field.
And therefore, how are you going to contribute?
to advance the field in whatever field you might choose.
You have to bring an expertise in one of the fields.
So either in physics, get a good basic background in physics or mathematics.
or geology, which would be related to my field, or in biology or engineering.
I think ocean engineering is kind of a new field, but going to be one that's increasingly important, already is important, in terms of building structures at sea, oil wells and things of this sort.
One of the basic sciences or engineering, I think, is going to be important.
One thing that's come along here at Woods Hole in the past few years has been a marine policy program.
And the social aspects of oceanography are increasingly important.
The legal aspects of oceanography, in terms of the Law of the Sea conference that seems to be never ending, probably never will end.
How are we limited?
How are we going to be limited in the future in terms of what we can do research on?
We're already being limited by excluding the continental shelves of the world to a large extent, except off our own shelves.
And we're going to have to develop political, bilateral relationships with other countries to be able to do research.
That's already limited the kind of work we can do in the oceans.
If the 200-mile limit is accepted throughout the world, that essentially closes off
about one-third or one-quarter of the world's oceans to research.
That's a big chunk.
If any country doesn't want research done off their shores 200 miles out, they can exclude any research being done.
Whereas 20 years ago, that was never a problem.
That's been a big change in Oceania.
But that's getting a little bit off the subject of what you asked me about.
Well, that's all right, because I was going to ask you about what you thought limits were to future oceanographers, in effect.
That's a major limitation I see right now.
Until we can get a major conference agreement, treaty, or whatever is required in the United Nations or elsewhere, we're going to have to deal, as an institution or as
if we're running ships, to deal with other countries to get clearance, either through our State Department or directly with the other countries, probably more likely through our State Department.
So we're going to have a bureaucratic limitation of just getting permission to work on other countries, in the territorial waters of other countries.
That means that everything will be slowed down, I think.
You'll have to request that permission years in advance, probably before you can get it.
So it means you have to do your planning much farther in advance than we used to do.
Instead of just going out on a cruise, planning it a few months ahead of time, you have to plan it years ahead of time.
And that's already happening.
We're seeing that now.
We're getting our own research programs planned years in advance.
Essentially, we're coming up to five-year plans, I think, is what we're doing.
Will that limit your data check, for example?
Suppose you wanted to...
You made some sort of an amazing discovery all at once in heat flow, and you wanted to check it out someplace else.
How would you know years in advance to apply that discovery?
It'll be difficult to do that.
It'll probably have to come about, if you want to go to a certain area very quickly, you'll have to work with another researcher in another country off whose shores you want to work.
You won't want to work with.
And maybe that's not so bad, because it means that that'll automatically require...
or require us to work with scientists in less developed countries, or someone in less developed countries, to be able to work there.
Maybe that'll force a kind of technology transfer that we keep arguing about in this country and finding ways of doing it.
But it may not, in the long run, be so bad for the Earth as a whole.
Somehow, we've got to distribute our knowledge and our expertise in oceanography to the rest of the world.
The United States leads the world, probably,
and like the rest of developed countries.
But we've got to get this expertise out to the rest of the world, too.
So there's a price we're probably going to pay for this lack of organized activity right now.
But in the long run, I think it may be beneficial.
A practical problem concerning
present world, as a matter of fact, is energy from the ocean.
Do you see, for example, thermal heat in your study offering any relief in terms of that?
I think our basic research in geothermal work now is directed partly to these problems.
How does hydrothermal circulation act in the oceans?
I think in the near future it's going to be difficult to exploit that heat.
There's a lot of heat coming up.
It's going to be difficult to exploit it, partly because
The heat coming out is at low temperatures.
Start with a few degrees above the background temperature of the deep oceans, which is almost freezing.
So it's very difficult to think of ways in which you could utilize such low temperature heat.
And it's also diffuse.
It comes out into the water and gets distributed right away.
You could think about drilling holes down into the areas where it's hot and piping out hot water, like is being talked about on land.
But it'll be that much more difficult in the oceans compared to the way it's being done on land.
On the other hand, some of these major geothermal areas in the oceans extend right up onto the continents.
One area I talked about before was the Gulf of California, where we found high heat flow.
And that's an area which is energy deficient.
which is near population centers, at least in Mexico, where we could perhaps be able to exploit the heat there, get it up on land and use it.
But it's going to require advanced technology.
I don't see this coming about in a realistic way for maybe 20 years at least.
I don't think the geothermal
that geothermal is going to be the solution to our energy problems.
It may contribute to a small extent in 10 or 20 years, but it's not a major...

I think the main contribution of our geothermal research at sea is understanding how the Earth works as a heat engine in general, and that the utilization of geothermal energy is mainly going to be on the continents.
But we may gain a lot of clues about how these systems work on continents from the way we study them in the oceans.
For example, it's a lot easier to make heat flow measurements on the ocean floor than it is on the continents.
We can make a lot more of them at a cheaper price.
And so we can understand hydrothermal systems in the oceans probably a lot more quickly than we can on the continents because of the difficulty of exploring on the continents.

And I don't think, you know, when you think about the heat that exists under continental areas, the rate at which we use energy in the United States is so large that the geothermal energy just can't provide any large fraction of this heat in any way.
I think solar energy is going to be much more important.
And the development of utilizing solar heat stored in the oceans
is going to be a more important aspect of getting energy out of the oceans than the geothermal part of it.
Excuse me, my voice just went out all of a sudden.
How do you feel the direction is going to go
in combining earth studies and ocean studies and things like weather prediction?
Do you feel as if the oceanographer of the future will be more broadly trained in terms of work with the land as well as the ocean?
Yeah.
Well, I think we'll still require the specialist in oceanography, but he's going to be part of a larger group, which probably is going to be more directed.
in structure than it has been in the past, rather than people going out at random to study things that they're interested in.
We're probably going to have more directed programs to understand these more applied aspects of oceanography, very important aspects of oceanography.
How do the oceans supply heat to the atmosphere and create the weather patterns that we see over the continents?
I think that's going to be a very important field in oceanography over the next 20, 30 years.
probably involving more dollars and more people than the geological aspects of oceanography.
Because the geology is not so urgent.

Well, you can't say that, too, because there are certain minerals and things that may be acquired in the oceans, manganese nodules and things of this sort, over the next few years that may become quite important.
I think we know quite a bit already about the distribution of those manganese nodules already from the expeditions that have gone on.
But there'll be more detailed work going on on an applied basis.
And as soon as these companies start mining this stuff, there'll be environmental aspects that we'll all have to worry about in the oceans.
What else?
That's all I have.
Do you have anything you'd like to add to the tape?
I don't think so unless I think of something right now.
I don't write at the moment.
Thank you.
